title: Investors ignoring growing global economic risks, RBA warns
text:
But this overly sanguine attitude to risk means that asset markets will be exposed to a violent sell-off if investors decide they should receive greater compensation for the risks they’re taking.

According to the Review, “asset prices are vulnerable to a destabilising correction if risk premiums were to rise suddenly. This could be triggered by a negative growth shock, geopolitical even, major credit event, or a normalisation in term premiums.”

There is also a risk that prices could tumble if yields on high-quality government bonds were to rise from their extremely low levels, if investors start to worry about emerging inflationary pressures despite tepid economic activity.

“Some asset holders may not be well prepared for such repricing, given a general increase in risk-taking in the low interest rate environment”, the Review warns. “This raises the prospect of large losses and reactive sales of assets, including by leveraged investors facing margin calls.”

Even if investors remain indifferent to investment risk, asset prices could come under pressure from a global economic slowdown.

That’s because the rise in asset prices over the past decade has occurred in tandem with an increase in global debt, leaving many households and corporates more vulnerable to adverse shocks.

“A sharp slowdown in growth could undermine global financial stability, including by reducing the capacity of highly leveraged borrowers to service their debts”, the Review warns.

It also points to the growing vulnerabilities of the massive US corporate debt market, where companies with higher debt levels, and lower interest cover account for more of the bonds issued.

As the Review notes, there is a risk that fund managers with mandates that require them to own bonds of a certain quality could be forced to sell large quantities of those bonds if companies suffer even a small rating downgrade.

In addition, certain sections of the US corporate bond market have suffered a deterioration in credit.

“Leveraged loans, which are loans extended to speculative grade or already highly leveraged firms, have also expanded rapidly in recent years”, the Review notes.
description: The Reserve Bank has sounded a warning bell about investor complacency at a time when the global economic outlook is deteriorating.
